occurrences.line_text: But after griefe awhile had had his course,
Directs her course vnto one certaine cost,
Whose course is often stayd, yet neuer is astray.
Though out of course, yet hath not bene mis-sayd,
But now I come into my course againe,
So as they coursed here and there, it chaunst
Him first from court he to the citties coursed,
Eftsoones dismounted from his courser braue,
And when he sate vpon his courser free,
Full strongly armd, and on a courser free,
Beares her away vpon his courser light:
Raunging the forest wide on courser free,
He smote his courser in the trembling flancke,
On goodly courser thundring with his feet,
Which well that valiant courser did discerne;
So proudly pricketh on his courser strong,
So fast as his good Courser could him beare,
Her Helmet, to her Courser mounting light:
Eftsoones his warlike courser, which was strayd
Fast flying on a Courser dapled gray,
An armed knight, vpon a courser strong,
But if thee list to see thy Courser ronne,
Vpon his Courser set the louely lode,
But hauing from his courser her downe throwne,
And eke the courser, whereuppon he rad,
Forth spurred fast: adowne his coursers side
And from their sweaty Coursers did auale,
And his wingfooted coursers him did beare
But till the horned moone three courses did expire.
That with the wind, contrary courses sew,
If wind and tide doe change, their courses change anew.
And search the courses of the rowling spheares,
Al which the heauens containe, & in their courses guide.
Thou doest not know the causes, nor their courses dew.
Like as the workeman had their courses taught;
That their well knowen courses they forwent,
So as they courst, and turneyd here and theare,
Them sorely vext, and courst, and ouerran,
There he him courst a fresh, and soone did make
And chose in Faery court of meere goodwill,
In liuing Princes court none euer knew
For in that court whylome her well they knew:
Yet goodly court he made still to his Dame,
With louely court he gan her entertaine;
Forthwith to court of Gloriane I sped,
But entred in a spacious court they see,
To Faery court thou cam'st to seeke for fame,
Of all, that royall Princes court became,
Sith him in Faerie court he late auizd;
Her once to show, ne court, nor dalliance,
But for in court gay portaunce he perceiu'd,
Eftsoones to court he cast t'auaunce his first degree.
To serue at court in view of vaunting eye;
And doest not it for ioyous court exchaunge,
The wood is fit for beasts, the court is fit for thee.
Did court the handmayd of my Lady deare,
Till him the Prince with gentle court did bord;
From Faery court. So talked they, the whiles
Where gentle court and gracious delight
Themselues to court, and each a Damsell chose:
Thus they awhile with court and goodly game,
And her to Faerie court safe to conuay,
From Faery court, where I haue many a day
And foure, since Florimell the Court for-went,
So farre from court and royall Citadell,
First she him sought in Court, where most he vsed
To Faery court she came, where many one
Which now in Faerie court all men do tell,
That has no skill of Court nor courtesie,
Therefore he her did court, did serue, did wooe,
Whom greatest Princes court would welcome fayne;
In Princes Court doe hap to sprout againe,
And out of court him scourged openly.
Vnto the Souldans court, her to present
When first to Faery court he saw her wend,
To Faerie Court, that of necessity
To Faery Court, where what him fell shall else be told.
And doe adorne your Court, where courtesies excell.
Of Court it seemes, men Courtesie doe call,
Right so in Faery court it did redound,
In Faery court, but him did deare embrace,
For on a day, when Cupid kept his court,
Him first from court he to the citties coursed,
And leauing home, to roiall court I sought;
She vsed most to keepe her royall court,
With fawning wordes he courted her a while,
And comely courted with meet modestie,
Courted of many a iolly Paramoure,
He courted her, yet bayted euery word,
Who faire him quited, as that courteous was:
And entertaines with comely courteous glee,
So courteous conge both did giue and take,
The knight was courteous, and did not forbeare
As to despise so courteous seeming part,
Of courteous clemencie in gentle hart.
So taking courteous conge he behight,
They courteous conge tooke, and forth together yode.
Of courteous knights, the Prince, and Faery gent,
Courteous to all, and seeming debonaire,
She that no lesse was courteous then stout,
With daily shew of courteous kind behauiour,
But mongst them all was none more courteous Knight,
Thy courteous lore, that doest my loue deride,
That well in courteous Calidore appeares,
Nathelesse, sith ye so courteous seemed late,
Glad would I surely be, thou courteous Squire,
So taking courteous leaue, they parted twayne,
The Ladie hearing his so courteous speach,
And for the courteous care, which he did beare
By late ensample of that courteous deed,
Yet was he courteous still to euery wight,
A courteous Knight, and full of faithfull trust:
And courteous withall, becomming her degree.
Such was the state of this most courteous knight
By all the courteous meanes he could inuent;
The Squire, for that he courteous was indeed,
With all the courteous glee and goodly feast,
(That was that courteous Knight, whom he before
Did litle whit regard his courteous guize,
But Calidore of courteous inclination
Thus did the courteous Knight excuse his blame,
To whom false Turpine comming courteously,
And them to tell him courteously besought,
All kindnesse and faire courtesie to shew;
Of milde demeanure, and rare courtesie,
Who them encounters with like courtesie;
Him answered, as courtesie became,
That has no skill of Court nor courtesie,
Nor more ennobled for their courtesie,
Yet let me you of courtesie request,
Then is the bloosme of comely courtesie,
Of Court it seemes, men Courtesie doe call,
For his exceeding courtesie, that pearst
But Calidore with all good courtesie
In th'end his kyndly courtesie to proue,
That he gainst courtesie so fowly did default.
Besought of courtesie in that his neede,
And offred him, his courtesie to requite,
In courtesie, and well could doe and say,
But he, that did in courtesie excell,
For courtesie amongst the rudest breds
All which she with such courtesie doth grace,
To shew the courtesie by him profest,
And doe adorne your Court, where courtesies excell.
With all kind courtesies, he could inuent;
Fit medcine to his griefe, and spake thus courtesly.
That the braue Mayd would not for courtesy,
And vnto him did shew all louely courtesyes.
With faire disport and courting dalliaunce
Feasting and courting both in bowre and hall;
Does faire entreat; no courting nicetie,
For courting fooles, that curtesies would faine,
Certes was but a common Courtisane,
Some frounce their curled haire in courtly guise,
Arrested all that courtly company,
Of comely seruices, or courtly trayne?
Does swim, and bathes himselfe in courtly blis,
With whom he meant to make his sport & courtly play.
And courtly seruices tooke no delight,
From courtly blisse and wonted happinesse,
Of courtly fauour, fed with light report,
Fell from high Princes courts, or Ladies bowres,
Of Magistrates, of courts, of tribunals,
Are wont in Princes courts to worke great scath and hindrance.
Your court'sie takes on you anothers due offence.
That court'sie doth as well as armes professe,
With all the court'sies, that she could deuise.
Who them requites with court'sies seeming meet,
And entertaine themselues with court'sies meet,
In Princes court,---The rest she would haue said,
He daily dyde, yet neuer throughly dyen couth.
Streight downe she ranne, like an enraged cow,
And siluer shield vpon his coward brest
To hide his coward head from dying dreed.
He was dismayed in his coward mind,
Disleall knight, whose coward courage chose
What coward hand shall doe thee next to die,
And crownd his coward crest with knightly stile;
His coward courage gan emboldned bee,
Then when he was defide, in coward corner ly.
Ne cared as a coward so to be condemned.
The coward Turpine, whereof now I treat;
So courage lent a cloke to cowardise.
To banish cowardize and bastard feare;
And with foule cowardize his carkasse shame,
As scorning his vnmanly cowardize:
For cowardize doth still in villany delight.
To shew such faintnesse and foule cowardize,
Yet durst he not for very cowardize
Or from the field most cowardly doth fly?
From fearefull cowards, entrance to forstall,
Were cowards knowne, and litle count did hold,
And for her sake a cowheard vile became,
The seruant of Admetus cowheard vile,
Flying from place to place with cowheard shame,
Kept by a cowheard, hight Eurytion,
Nor vndertake the same, for cowheard feare,
Vile cowheard dogge, now doe I much repent,
And crime to crime, by this thy cowheard feare.
Therewith the cowheard deaded with affright,
Cowherd (quoth she) were not, that thou wouldst fly,
And euermore that crauen cowherd Knight
Through cowherd feare he fled away as fast,
But Coridon for cowherdize reiect,
And she coy lookes: so dainty they say maketh derth.
Still solemne sad, or still disdainfull coy,
Another seemed enuious, or coy,
And euerie looke was coy, and wondrous quaint,
And coy lookes tempring with loose dalliance;
Nor sense of man so coy and curious nice,
Seeing his face so louely sterne and coy,
But this coy Damzell thought contrariwize,
He of his name Coylchester built of stone and lime.
Then Coyll, and after him good Lucius,
But shortly was by Coyll in battell slaine:
With whom king Coyll made an agreement,
Coyly rebutted his embracement light;
Her deedes were forged, and her words false coynd,
And in his lap a masse of coyne he told,
Gan coyne streight lawes to curb their liberty;
That they haue crusht the Crab, and quite him borne
Of swarth complexion, and of crabbed hew,
Therein a cancred crabbed Carle does dwell,
And makes her ribs to cracke, as they were torne,
Ne yet hath any knight his courage crackt.
For else my feeble vessell crazd, and crackt
It crackt throughout, yet did no bloud appeare;
Was crackt in twaine, but by his foolish feere
Sith to thee is vnknowne the cradle of thy brood.
Whiles yet in infant cradle he did crall;
And all the Graces rockt her cradle being borne.
Euen from the cradle of his infancie,
Swift Atalanta, when through craft he her out ran.
In leaches craft, by great Appolloes lore,
And perfectly practiz'd in womans craft,
Thereto the villaine vsed craft in fight;
For he right well in Leaches craft was seene,
Which cunning Craftesman hand hath ouerlayd
Wherewith the Craftesman wonts it beautify,
Doth meet a cruell craftie Crocodile,
Her craftie head was altogether bald,
This craftie messenger with letters vaine,
Still as he went, he craftie stales did lay
To seeke that knight, where him that craftie Squire
Therefore this craftie engine he did frame,
His craftie engin, and as he had sayd,
Ah but (said craftie Trompart) weete ye well,
And closely tempted with their craftie spyes;
And eke himselfe had craftily deuisd
But Coridon escaping craftily,
So cunningly she wrought her crafts assay,
As to descry the crafty cunning traine,
And whilest he bath'd, with her two crafty spyes,
Still did she roue at her with crafty glaunce
Her crafty engins to her close intent.
This crafty Paramoure, and now it plaine displayd.
For he so crafty was to forge and face,
Farre vnderneath a craggie clift ypight,
Of mightie Magnes stone, whose craggie clift
That gainst the craggy clifts did loudly rore,
But chaunced on a craggy cliff to light;
But with his craggy club in his right hand,
And dauncing on the craggy cliffes at will;
And further did vncomely speaches crake.
Leasings, backbytings, and vaine-glorious crakes,
Which swarming all about his legs did crall,
Whiles yet in infant cradle he did crall;
Whence he with crooked clawes so long did crall,
And like a Crane his necke was long and fyne,
One cald the Theise, the other cald the Crane;
And stalking stately like a Crane, did stryde
With vgly craples crawling in their way,
Her crased health, her late recourse to rest,
Whereof he crau'd redresse. My Soueraine,
And entraunce crau'd, which was denied erst.
Crau'd leaue of Alma, and that aged sire,
Their counsell crau'd, in daunger imminent.
And pardon crau'd for his so rash assault,
Which of all earthly things he most did craue;
Saying, Yet O thou dreaded Dame, I craue
That still for carrion carcases doth craue:
And happie ease, which thou doest want and craue,
Therefore I ought craue pardon, till I there haue beene.
The thing, that thou didst craue so earnestly,
That craue but rowme to rest, while tempest ouerblo'th.
Let me this craue, sith first I was defyde,
Therefore I humbly craue your Maiestie,
To craue the same, whom errour so misled,
Yet since ye mercie now doe need to craue,
Let me this craue, vnworthy though of it,
Yet if he needes will fight, craue leaue till morne,
The which doth litle craue contented to abyde.
With which those Amazons his loue still craued,
A bloudy crosse, and on his crauen crest
There he this most discourteous crauen found,
And euermore that crauen cowherd Knight
So hauing from his crauen bodie torne
Much did the Crauen seeme to mone his case,
For misery craues rather mercie, then repriefe.
That house-rome craues, yet would be loth t'assay
That pitty craues, as he of woman was yborne.
Crauing of you in pitty of my state,
Then crauing sucke, and then the sucke refusing.
She staid: with that he crauld out of his nest,
With vgly craples crawling in their way,
For else my feeble vessell crazd, and crackt
And flame with gold, but the white fomy creame,
And euery head was crowned on his creast,
Ne reard aboue the earth his flaming creast,
Bad her old Squire vnlace her lofty creast;
So sore he sowst him on the compast creast,
Ne euer Knight, that bore so lofty creast,
Is creasted all with lines of firie light,
And ill becomes you with your loftie creasts,
In heauen and earth? did not he all create
Do not I kings create, and throw the crowne
It told, how first Prometheus did create
And she whom Nature did so faire create,
All things, as they created were, doe grow,
As it at first created was of yore.
For since the day that they created beene,
For at the first they all created were
Their dainty parts, which nature had created
The Witch creates a snowy Lady,
She by creation was, till she did fall;
Of his creation, when he life began,
And all her whole creation did her shew
And his faire sister for creation
The grace of his Creator doth despise,
Found no defect in his Creatours grace,
The great Creatours owne resemblance bright,
As her Creatresse had in charge to her ordained.
That such a cursed creature liues so long a space.
And that new creature borne without her dew,
That liuing creature mote it not abide;
When euery creature shrowded is in sleepe;
Deformed creature, on a filthie swyne,
Descends to hell: there creature neuer past,
Yet crime in her could neuer creature find,
Where liuing creature none he did espye;
More vgly shape yet neuer liuing creature saw.
So faire a creature yet saw neuer sunny day.
As in great muse, ne word to creature spake.
Yet wist no creature, whence that heauenly sweet
They neuer creature saw, that came that way.
One cursed creature, he by chaunce espide,
A goodly creature, whom he deemd in mind
Might looke, that maketh euery creature glad,
If ay more goodly creature thou didst see;
The fairest creature, that he euer saw,
No liuing creature could his cruelty asswage.
But she a mortall creature loued best:
That liuing creature it would terrify,
Sith that more bounteous creature neuer far'd
Whereas no liuing creature he mistooke,
Yet liuing creature none she saw appeare:
And to her seruice bind each liuing creature;
And weend no mortall creature she should bee,
With fleshly weaknesse, which no creature may
To worke such outrage on so faire a creature?
This vgly creature in his armes her snatcht,
Ne creature saw, but hearkned now and then
A foule and lothsome creature did appeare;
A foule and loathly creature sure in sight,
For neuer two so like did liuing creature see.
Full weake and crooked creature seemed she,
So faire a creature, and so wondrous bold,
So vgly creature, she was nigh dismayd,
I should no creature ioyne vnto mine ayde,
For seldome yet did liuing creature see,
Where foot of liuing creature neuer troade,
Who can aread, what creature mote she bee,
Whether a creature, or a goddesse graced
Ten thousand kindes of creatures, partly male
Does care for looke of liuing creatures eye.
The cursed creatures doe eternally torment.
Deformed creatures, horrible in sight,
That made him scorne all creatures great and small,
Most cursed of all creatures vnder skye,
In heauenly spirits to these creatures bace,
Of highest God, that loues his creatures so,
Deformed creatures, in straunge difference,
Compared to the creatures in the seas entrall.
T'afflict the creatures, which therein did dwell,
Yet tract of liuing creatures none they found,
Infinite shapes of creatures men do fynd,
Infinite shapes of creatures there are bred,
And vnto all his creatures so benigne,
More happie creatures, then they seem'd to bee,
And to his law compels all creatures to obay.
The fertile Nile, which creatures new doth frame;
Which being ment of mortall creatures sead,
For she all liuing creatures did excell;
And all his creatures from their course astray,
All creatures must obey the voice of the most hie.
The earth to all her creatures lodging lends.
Two griesly creatures; and, to that their faces
Ne let it seeme, that credence this exceedes,
That him too light of credence did mislead,
His credit now in doubtfull ballaunce hong;
And they more fond, that credit to thee giue,
His glory did repose, and credit did maintaine.
After lost credite and consumed thrift,
Or care of credite, or of husband old,
The carefull cold beginneth for to creepe,
When courage first does creepe in manly chest,
Whereby close fire into his heart does creepe:
Through which the damned ghosts doen often creepe
Low his lasciuious armes adown did creepe,
Euer to creepe into his noble brest,
Or creepe betweene his legs, so in to goe,
That neither could to company of th'other creepe.
Into the same he creepes, and thenceforth there
Creepes forth of dores, whilst darknes him doth hide,
The drouping Night thus creepeth on them fast,
And creeping sought way in the weedy gras:
The creeping deadly cold away did shake:
At last with creeping crooked pace forth came
Those creeping flames by reason to subdew,
So creeping close, as Snake in hidden weedes,
Close creeping twixt the marrow and the skin.
Forth creeping on his caitiue hands and thies,
Whiles creeping slomber made him to forget
In which they creeping did at last display
So that at last a little creeping sleepe
Yet afterwards close creeping, as he might,
That creeping close, amongst the hiues to reare
Came to her creeping like a fawning hound,
And creeping still behinde, doth him incomber,
Creeping behinde him still to haue destroyde:
Early before the Morne with cremosin ray,
Into her mouth they crept, and suddain all were gone.
Then he by cunning sleights in at the window crept.
Downe fell to ground, and crept into a bush,
He closely nearer crept, the truth to weet:
Vpon his hands and feete he crept full light,
So closely as he could, he to them crept,
And he emongst the rest crept forth in sory plight.
Crept in by stouping low, or stealing of the kaies.
Mongst which crept litle Angels through the glittering gleames.
A bloudy crosse, and on his crauen crest
And hide thy head. Therewith vpon his crest
Therewith vpon his crest he stroke him so,
For all the crest a Dragon did enfold
Vpon the top of all his loftie crest,
Eftsoones he gan aduance his haughtie crest,
Vpon his crest the hardned yron fell,
But his more hardned crest was armd so well,
And standing stoutly vp, his loftie crest
Wherewith he smote his haughty crest so hye,
That quite it cloue his plumed crest in tway,
That in the lake his loftie crest was steept,
And crownd his coward crest with knightly stile;
Smote him so hugely on his haughtie crest,
His crest was couered with a couchant Hound,
Thenceforth the feather in her loftie crest,
That made him low incline his lofty crest,
He bare, and by the colours in his crest,
Tho whenas vailed was her loftie crest,
And falling heauie on Cambelloes crest,
That in her wheeling round, behind her crest
Eftsoones that warriouresse with haughty crest
Vpon his crested scalpe so sore did smite,
And lowly did abase their loftie crests
And rearing fiercely their vpstarting crests,
And high aduaunced crests downe meekely feld,
Where one stood peeping through a creuis small,
Like euer saw. And there a noble crew
Right glad with him to haue increast their crew:
Such one was Gluttony, the second of that crew.
Haue thither come the noble Martiall crew,
But that faire crew of knights, and Vna faire
A noble crew about them waited round
Another Damsell of that gentle crew,
Of Neustria come roring, with a crew
Now that he had her singled from the crew
The loue and seruice of the basest crew?
Whereas she found the Goddesse with her crew,
But or some Goddesse, or of Dianes crew,
Now when this gallant with his goodly crew,
Vnmindfull both of that discordfull crew,
Appear'd in place, with all his noble crew:
There he in troupe found all that warlike crew,
But Satyrane boue all the other crew,
Alas for pittie that so faire a crew,
This gentle crew gan from their eye-lids chace
Mote we entreat you, sith this gentle crew
These marched farre afore the other crew;
The eares and hearts of all that goodly crew,
Full many people gathered in a crew:
In the base blood of such a rascall crew;
Of all the rest, and then this warlike crew
To set afresh on all the other crew.
Made cruell hauocke of the baser crew,
Ne ceassed not, till all their scattred crew
Then found he many missing of his crew,
Did her beseeme. And euer, as the crew
Where was his Pastorell? where all the other crew?
There this faire crewe arriuing, did diuide
Yt seemd th'enchaunted flame, which did CreÃ¼sa wed.
